talks.title: Trivial Notions
talks.speaker: Matthew Niemiro (Harvard)
talks.description: The greatest stories do not begin with oo-category theory, and neither will ours. The germs of semiadditivity subsist willingly upon ordinary categories, ready for swab and cultivation. We will start our seminar by documenting some of the most basic semiadditive phenomena (in particular: bilimits, enrichments, norms, and ambidexterity for negative one and zero semiadditivity) as it is expressible in ordinary language. Then we will anticipate extensions of the theory. Finally, we will create a hostage situation to canvass speakers.

talks.title: I am NORMal and can be trusted with BOTH MY LEFT AND RIGHT HANDS
talks.speaker: Matthew Niemiro (Harvard)
talks.description: In this session, we will make the first definition of semiadditivity using ambidexterity and norms. The basic idea is that semiadditivity amounts to the existence of certain bilimits, hence it is a property concerning certain families F : X \to C where F and X are variable. This, in turn, may be understood inductively by analyzing the existence and invertibility of norm maps. But there's still a lot going on. The role of ambidexterity is to isolate that part of semiadditivity concerning X in a functorial and controllable manner, and this will help us run the machine. In particular, we will use ambidexterity to construct relative integration, a “higher” form of addition that will clarify the existence problem for norms.

talks.title: Spanish
talks.speaker: Sam Munoz-Echaniz (MIT)
talks.description: We previously defined semiadditivity using ambidexterity. The essential byproduct of ambidexterity was integration, which is a "higher" addition we used to construct norms. In this talk, we will see just how essential integration was: we will discuss the relationship between spans and addition, characterize semiadditivity in spanish, and discuss examples.
